Concept ACK\n\nPerhaps we should get rid of the `else`-case log message (“Not using config file”) to increase signal to noise in our logging?

@practicalswift I'm ok with removing the else statement, but the reason I added this is to improve the user experience. Currently a user has no reliable feedback regarding where bitcoind is getting config values. If an invalid conf file path is passed in, bitcoind doesn't tell the user this file doesn't exist and says it's using the file. If we remove the else statement, the user will have no idea

@leishman Good point! I think @Sjors suggestion is a good compromise – to show the “Not using config file” only if `-conf` is set.\n\nutACK ac7771d4388ca82a4e36fc058cb328b2860ed7c9 assuming @Sjors suggestion is implemented :-)

@practicalswift @Sjors the reason i didn't add that extra condition was for the following scenario: A user creates a `bitcoin.conf` file in the wrong directory and they can't figure out why bitcoind is not using their settings. At least with this change they will be able to see where bitcoind is looking by default for a configuration file and they will know that bitcoind does not see what it's loo
@leishman that makes sense. Perhaps if `-conf` is not set, the error could say "No file exists _at the default location_ %s", but maybe that's overkill.
@Sjors I don't think it hurts, as this is a known source of confusion for new users. I've updated with your suggestion and tested on Mac. Anyone have a windows machine they can test on?
@practicalswift thanks for the suggestions and for catching the typo. I've updated accordingly.
